description.text:
Smartphone car support.

This model was designed to use with Volkswagen Polo 2015 version. The support is installed in the front cup holder using Part_1.

You can use this model with smartphones 10 mm wide.

You can send me your car holder and smartphone measurements and I can try to design one support for you.

I have attached SolidWorks designs if you want to modify them.

The version 2.0 used 4 springs to join Part_3 and Part_4 in order to you can introduce any smartphone.

You can glue the pieces together to form a solid, becasue you can introduce the phone without remove the part 2. This solution allows to eliminate the clearances between the pieces.

Notes:

If you live in a hot city, like Seville, I recomend you to use ABS instead of PLA due to the high temperatures could deform the pieces (it's happened to me ^^').

Assembly

I recomend glue the Part_1 to Part_2, Part_2 to Part_3 and Part_3 to Part 5 using cold welding compound in order to produce a good join between the parts.

You should use 31 mm length springs and glue into the holes in Part_4 and Part_3.
These are CTC-optimized arms for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:673801 because in my case the extruder carriage strikes against the original arms, when the z-axis was up

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

title: shower curtains pipe fastener replacement thingy

description.text:
Oke i hate these shower curtain things because after i while they tend to get loose an so you keep pushing them up until you are fed up with it and buy a new one.
Why do they get loose ? Well the design is wrong (maybe). If you jam them in the pipe the force will fade away after a while.
So i made these, they will apply the force from inside out, when the turn the bold the fastener will get pulled in pressing the split up tube part into the wall of the pipe.
I hope this will work better than the ikea one ;-)
printing the conner (bend pieces) is a bit tricky i tried bend.stl en bend2.stl both need support but both work. but i think version3 (to be made) (splitting the bend up in two parts) might be the best option for printing but then you would have to glue them together it could also do with a pair of wall mounts but i did not need then so feel free to make your own ;-)
The hole thing is made with parameters in mind, so it would work with different pipe diameters.
Mine where
outerDiameterPipe = 30
innerDiameterPipe = 26.5
innerRadiusBend = 10
I don't know if anyone needs these but he the world is a big place

Just make one
Print one set of fastner2xv3.stl
Print bend.stl or bend2.stl (both with exterior support)
Use a M3 40 mm bolt and nut and bolt the thing together but don't overdo it it still has to fit to pipe
Insert it into te pipe and tighten the bolt some more it will now lock into place.
Do the same on the other end
Make a mod
Goto
https://github.com/elmom/MCAD
Download
https://github.com/elmom/MCAD/blob/master/metric_fastners.scad
Open
shower_curtains_pipe fastener.scad and change settings

comments.text: Thanks!! Same curtain, same problem. Printing.

Modification and redesign of existing pipettes on Thingiverse to allow dispensing using commercial 200ul pipette tips. I have yet to calibrate it and measure its accuracy, but this will come down to the setting and fit of the lower gear. My dispensations of liquids have been very consistent so far. The idea was to move from getting suction from a balloon membrane to instead using a plunger and a tube as I had difficulties with retaining the siphon pressure. The things you need to get it to work besides the prints are the following: 3 o-rings (3 x 7 mm) in EPDM, Nitrile or other suitable material
PEZ dispenser spring or similar
Lubricant
Commercial tips, such as from Eppendorf To print, use the highest possible setting for the plunger, gears and the pipette tube. I used 100% infill with 2 shells. Use 15% infill for the main body. Prior to assembly, I suggest you have sand paper ready and try to assemble the plunger with o-rings and pass them through the pipette tube to make sure you have a good fit. Have some water handy and test its fit and suction like you would with a syringe. I suggest you lubricate the o-rings to make this work better. When you are happy with the fit and function, with as little friction as possible while retaining the siphon effect, disassemble and go on for the final assembly. To assemble, put the pipette tube into the main body and push it in all the way so it protrudes slightly at the top opening. On the plunger, thread the spring. Now the more tricky part. Insert the gears into the top cavity and thread the tip of the plunger into the top opening and through the centre of the gears. With the tip of the plunger protruding through the lower gear, use your fingers or tweezers to slide over the three o-rings. Lubricate them in advance as well as the opening of the tube as this may facilitate the process. The tip of the plunger has two recesses. The o-rings should be fitted so that the middle ring is locked in place by a top and bottom o-ring in their recesses. When in place, insert the tip of the plunger into the pipette tube and start rotating the gears so that the plunger is inserted further into the pipette and until the top gear can no longer be turned. Test the spring function and the siphon effect and calibrate as needed. I have further modified mine to use a stronger spring as the PEZ one was a bit weak and I will likely redesign the plunger to accomodate a round spring soon, unless anyone beats me to it! I hope this is useful to any DIY biologist or molecular gastronomist out there =)

comments.text:
I just printed one of these and just need a spring and some o-rings now. From my measurements the o-rings should be approx. 3mm ID x 2 mm thickness, maybe a bit more to ensure a proper seal.
The inner diameter of the tip is 7 mm, the outer diameter of the grooves in the plunger is 3 mm. That gives me 2 mm distance between tip and plunger grooves. The spot for the third o-ring has an outer diameter of 4 mm. Let's see...

print_settings.Notes:: Be aware that ABS is more flexible than PLA and this may result in additional vertical movement and springiness, and thus extra camera vibration.  Then again, the same trait may instead allow the mount to better dampen the vibration instead of transmitting it to the camera; I'm not sure which.

title: Dyne's Wanhao Y-Carriage C920 Camera Mount & Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Edit 2016-07-11: Added a new STL file for the latest version of the mount. It includes pads attached to the corners to help prevent ABS warping; just break them off before installing. The other changes are a 1.5 mm thicker stiffening ridge and a more gradual curve on the support block.

This is a webcam mounting bar for the print bed (Y axis) of the Wanhao Duplicator i3 and its cousins, plus an adapter that attaches the folding base of a Logitech C920 webcam -- or really any reasonably small camera with a 1/4" tripod mount -- to it.

Note: Due to the potential proximity between the camera and the print head, it may or may not be possible to use this if you have a front-mounted part cooling fan/duct installed, such as the stock fan or the diiicooler. You will have to measure the clearance carefully. I was already using thorped's wanhao fan duct (which is rear mounted) so this wasn't an issue for me.

This was inspired by dumbcomputers' Wanhao i3 Camera Bed Mount. The adapter portion was originally intended to attach to the flat portion of that, but I ultimately designed my own version in an effort to shift the camera away from the printer's home position (more toward the center of the X axis and further out from the bed). The adapter STL is still compatible with dumbcomputers' mount, but note that doing this places the camera very close to the print head. They may come in contact every time the printer homes or prints anything along the front edge of the build area unless you manually rotate the camera out of the way as needed.

Since the (relatively heavy) camera sits at the end of a piece of plastic that behaves like a diving board anytime the bed changes direction or there are rapid X axis movements, there is a limit to the length that can be given to the mount to move the camera further away without pushing the vibration to unacceptable levels.

An example of a timelapse recorded using this mount; the model being printed was V2 of my Finial Tetra

Printer:

Maker Select v2 (Wanhao di3)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

50% on mount. <=25% on adapter

Notes:

This lies fairly close to the bed heater, since it mounts to the lower of the two aluminum plates that make up the bed. Hot air rises, and this both lies below the heater and is attached to a largish heat sink (the aluminum plates), so it stays somewhat insulated from convection and conducted heat.

I printed the prototypes in eSun Orange and Green PLA+, so I covered the mount (not the adapter) with a small piece of aluminum foil to help provide a little shielding from radiated heat as well, but I still got a little drooping after a few days of printing PLA. This may have been exacerbated by the C920's weight and extended length of the mount. I expect it would be worse at higher temps, and since there is nearly zero clearance between this part and the front frame of the Y-carriage, I would highly recommend printing this in ABS or other high-temperature plastic to prevent that.

Be aware that ABS is more flexible than PLA and this may result in additional vertical movement and springiness, and thus extra camera vibration. Then again, the same trait may instead allow the mount to better dampen the vibration instead of transmitting it to the camera; I'm not sure which.

Instructions and Additional Hardware
  • One (1) 1/4" UNC (coarse thread) screw. Approximately 1/2 inch long. In a pinch, you can use a 3/4 inch screw, plus a nut or some washers or something as spacers between the screwhead and the adapter. A screw any longer than that might not clear the frame.
  • Four (4) M4 screws, any style (flathead would be easiest). 8-12 mm in length
  • Two (2) M4 screws. This pair must be flathead in order to clear the frame when the bed moves forward. 12-16 mm in length or so. Use the longer option if you want to use the optional nuts below.
  • Optional: Two M4 nuts (for the flathead screws that attach the adapter)

  1. Install either my Y mount, or the flat part from dumbcomputers (you'll have to split his STL using Meshmixer or similar). To install, you will first need to remove the upper portion of the print bed from the lower portion. Since this involves removing the bed leveling screws, springs, and washers, this is a good time to do any mods that you want that require removing these. For example: the nylock nut mod, the bed spring retainers, and some of the glass bed clips). Use the first four M4 screws to attach the mount to the lower aluminum plate, and through that to the front-left Y bearing block (in place of the existing screws that hold on the block).

  2. Use the two flathead screws (and optionally, nuts) to attach the adapter to your chosen mount. The screws should self-thread, but you can manually tap the holes if you have an M4 tap. On my mount, the adapter slots into the space at the end of the raised ridge, where there are only two screw holes. The screws are inserted from the bottom upward.

  3. Use the 1/4 inch screw to attach the webcam's tripod mount to the adapter.

One idea I've had is to create a vibration dampener that sits between the mount and the underside of the heater. It has to be a bit springy to account for different bed heights, and because if it's too rigid it will deform the bed by pressing upward.

Also, if you do not use a logitech C920, you may wish to make your own adapter. Much like dumbcomputers before me, the adapter is a separate part in order to permit you to change or remove the camera without the need to dismantle the bed a second time.

At time of writing, the dimensions of the imaginary rectangular space where the adapter sits between the raised ridge and the curved support piece (i.e., where the adapter screw holes are located) are 12 mm x 35 mm. The holes for the M4 screws are centered within that rectangle; the centers are 6mm from either long edge, 8.5 mm from the nearest short edge, and 18 mm apart from one another. (To put it another way, the holes are centered at 9 mm from the midline of that end of the mount, and 6mm from the end, not counting the support piece.) They are 3.85 mm in diameter to allow some grip for threads.

The curved support piece on the end of my mount (which slots between the pair of braces on the underside of my adapter) is 8 mm wide and 8 mm above the rectangle described in the previous paragraph (adding the 4 mm thickness of the mount, it's a total of 12 mm tall).

title: iBoardbot: an OPEN SOURCE internet remotely controlled drawing robot

description.text:
https://youtu.be/zr3JZYXoIVg

The iBoardbot:

The iBoardbot is an ARDUINO robot connected to the internet capable of writing texts and drawing with great precision. Also, it can erase in a quick and effective way. Send to your iBoardbot your information from any part of the world. As it has a multi-user interface you can also play and challenge your kids, use it as a collaborative notice board or as a twitter wall in your store window.

Features:

Drawing mode:

It can precisely draw what you assign to it. Different users will be able to collaborate with the drawing at the same time from different devices and world places. No matter how far the drawer is; the drawing precision will be as if the drawer himself was holding the pen with his hands

Graphics mode:

Upload and draw your own graphics using the iBoardbot´s webAPP!

Text mode:

Send any text. The iBoardbot will adjust it to the right size so it can fit on the board and it will draw it using its own font. Just type it and click/tap on SEND

IFTTT integrated:

Why not send the subject of an email you just have received to the iBoardbot? Or the last SMS you got? Or the temperature of your home? Or the weather forecast? What about the last tweet from your favourite music band? or… there are as many possibilities as possible recipes. Some recipes created by users at http://jjrobots.com/iboardbots-ifttt-recipes/ (more to come!)

What IFTTT is:
http://jjrobots.com/iboardbot-ifttt-recipes-how-to/ UPDATE, may 2017: some 3D parts have been modified to make them simpler to print with any 3D printer

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

0.35

Notes:

There is no need to print the pieces with support. Everything printed with CURA (and no problems so far)

LIST OF MATERIALS:

·GT2 timing belt (two segments of 53+100 cms)
·pulley gt2 20 tooth
·608 bearing
·623 bearing
·Stainless steel round bar (8mmØ,450mm length)
·2x round anodised aluminium tube (6mmØ, 205 mm length)
·4x 30 cms servo cable extender
·2x 1.8deg HIGH QUALITY NEMA 17 Stepper motors (40mm length) (4.4Kg/cm torque)
·Motor cables (14+70 cms length do the job)
·2x SG90 servo
·Arduino Leonardo compatible
·B-robot Brain Shield 2.1 or...similar
·Power supply 12v/2A
·2x copper bushing (8x11×22)
·6mm M3 bolts
·16mm M3 bolts
·M3 nuts
·1x M3 self locking nuts

OTHERS:

-3mm wide/100mm long zip ties (~x10)
-5mmØ cable wrap (~90 cms)
-1x Staedtler MARKER (black)
-CLOUD SERVICE subscription

You can also buy everything(iBoardbot customizable KIT): here
or create all the jjRobots with the MOST AWESOME ROBOTICS KIT

How to set it up?

Take a look to this link: http://jjrobots.com/iboardbot-assembly-instructions/

The elements needed to create your own iBoardbot Info, code, assembly guide and community available at:
Code and 3D parts:

https://github.com/jjrobots/iBoardbot (code and 3D parts)

Assembly guide:

http://jjrobots.com/iboardbot-assembly-instructions/

How to control the iboardbot:

http://jjrobots.com/?p=2945

Community:

https://jjrobots.com/forum/

B-robot EVO 2: another robot created using the same electronics and motors used in the iBoardbot

Hi Paul. the iBoardbot is a sort of "hack" of a regular glass shelf and a 3D printer. We wanted different users to collaborate drawing at the same time from different devices and world places like they were locally drawing with a invisible hand .

This two part grommet is for HDS single Ethernet installations with LSS and N2k.
Instructions:
1 - drill 3mm pilot hole where you want the grommet
2 - drill 9mm hole 13.5mm to the left of the pilot hole as per diagram
3 - drill 25mm hole in pilot hole with hole saw
4 - Put cables through hole starting with LSS, then transducer (sonar), then Ethernet, then power/data cable (tail end, not plug end) and finally N2k
5 - Clip cables into each half
6 - Place halves together, align 'key' and insert into hole gently

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/guLi5Y0sXZx

A mini digger executive toy. 4 moveable joints, rotating base, 2 arm joints and bucket control from the 2 levers at the back. These are available as kits through my website.
http://msraynsford.blogspot.com/2012/01/mini-digger.html
Simply cut out and assemble with M3 bolts. The two main joints require 35mm long bolts which are slightly tricky to get but the holes can easily be drilled to 4mm and M4 bolts used instead.

comments.text: Beautiful! I just cut one of these out of 1/8" (3mm) acrylic. Fit is perfect, design is great, all is fantastic. I'll tell you, this little guy is screaming for some servos, though. I think I am going to have to robot-ify this as well as maybe scale it up a bit and do it on the CNC instead of the laser. BTW --Was it your intention to use BB's for the bearing at the base? I thought that I was the one who invented that. At any rate, the fit was perfect and an even number of BB's fit in the groove with no spaces in between. Perfect. Absoulutly perfect. Thank you my friend.

description.text: Here is a fan box to sit over the MKS V1.3 board on my Hictop Printer. I've looked everywhere for something like this but I've had no luck. I've updated the file to have a smaller and centered opening for the USB cable.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Hictop

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Resolution and Infill are up to you. I'm printing in PLA but I'm sure ABS would be much better.

I have test fitted the cooling box with the fan mounted and it fits perfectly...aside from the USB relief on the side of the box.(which is now fixed as of 06/09/16) the new model and installation pics will be up soon.
Part list:

  1. 80mm 2 wire fan
    2.(4)M3x20 nylon stand-offs
    3.(4)M3x45 bolts
  2. Set of mounting nuts & bolts to mount the fan to fan box.

comments.text: Yes...a couple of factors you need to consider is the width of your fan you plan on installing and how your stepper and thermistor wiring is routed. And if your running into depth fitment issues you could use slightly larger standoffs. This box was designed with the correct size standoffs to have no fitment issues...just print and mount but because no two printers are alike you may need to modify your wiring and connectors. Send pics after you print and mount the box.

author: Retrogrand

description.text: Hmm

Dessicase

This is a cheapo way to keep your 3D printer filament dry. The setup is
for 1.75mm filament, so the feeder section would need to be re-mixed for a
fitting that will handle 3mm.

Tools:

10 minute epoxy.
Pipe Tap, 1/8 NPT-27:
http://www.amazon.com/Vermont-American-20371-Carbon-Steel/dp/B000K1LZ76?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00
A tap handle if you don't have one.
Coarse sandpaper or a wood file.
Needle nose pliers.

Parts:
Printed:
2x DesicaseHub01
1x DesicaseFeeder
4x Dessicase_corner00
1x Dessicase_corner01a
1x Dessicase_corner02a
1x Dessicase_corner03
1x Dessicase_corner04

Fitting: Straight Quick Connector Pneumatic 4mm x 1/8" PT Male Thread:
http://www.amazon.com/uxcell-Straight-Connectors-Pneumatic-Fittings/dp/B00FH6FIQI?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00

1/4" Dowels:

5x DowelX      79mm
4x DowelDiag  138mm
4x DowelY     208mm
4x DowelZ     222mm
1x Dowel Axle  93mm

Ziploc Freezer Bag, 2 Gallon, 13" X 15":
http://www.amazon.com/Ziploc-Freezer-Bags-Gallon-Count/dp/B00HXCNNN4/ref=sr_1_1_a_it?ie=UTF8&qid=1464278523&sr=8-1&keywords=ziploc+freezer+2+gallon
also trying out:
http://www.amazon.com/pieces-Gallon-Reclosable-Freezer-Storage/dp/B009ZL3S5Y?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00
4mm Tubing, teflon works well:
http://www.amazon.com/Meters-Filament-3D-printer-Rostock/dp/B00THZKC8Y?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00

10g Silica Gel Dessicant Pack

Instructions:

  • Cut 1/4" dowels to the indicated lengths.
  • Sand or file the rough edges on the dowels.
  • Print the parts. I've used ABS and PETG with good results;
    let me know if other materials work, thanks.
  • Make sure a dowel will fit into every socket.
  • Tap the hole for the fitting, doesn't have to be
    extremely deep.
  • Arrange the dowels by size; put the axle dowel to the
    side so you don't glue it.
  • Mix a small amount of adhesive (I've used wood glue and
    hot melt glue as well). I use a small medicine cup.
  • Don't glue the axle or Feeder part (with the 4mm fitting).
  • Glue everything else.
  • Let sit for an hour or so - wood glue overnight, hot melt
    until it's cool.
  • Place the assembled frame in a ziploc bag, and push the
    bag down so the axle sockets are easily accessible.
  • Pierce the bag at the center of the fitting.
  • Slide the bag around to the side of the fitting, and
    enlarge the hole with a pencil.
  • Slide the bag back so the hole is over the fitting, and
    gently slide the hole over the plastic head of the fitting.
  • Place the dessicant pack in the bottom of the bag.
  • Feed filament from the spool through the fitting.
  • Slide the filament spool into the frame so the axle dowel
    can make it through the center of the spool.
  • Feed the axle dowel through the center of the spool, and
    slide the dowel into the hub sockets.
  • Close up the ziploc bag.
  • Cut a 2 1/4" length of tubing.
  • Seal one end of the tubing - I've used hot melt glue, tape
    and heat shrink tubing.
  • Slightly crush the tubing in the middle, so that when the
    filament is inserted it's gripped nicely.
  • Slide the filament end into the tubing so that it's held
    and slide the tubing into the fitting.
  • Your filament is now sealed from the elements.

Notes:

For printing, I'm using:

0.4mm nozzle
0.198mm layer
2 walls
35% infill
No raft or support

To print the full kit it's taking me a bit over 2.5 hours.

To use the filament, press in on the plastic part of the fitting
to release the tubing, pulling the filament with it. Make sure
the dessicant doesn't interfere with the spool.

On my main printer I use a longer section of the tubing to connect
the Dessicase to the Bowden extruder.

Enjoy!

Edit 20160626: Added feed collar gadget, which keeps the feed tube from going into my EZStruder.

Printer:

BI2.5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.198

Infill:

35%

Notes:

0.4mm nozzle

remixed_from.author: jamesarm97
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Controller replacement backplate

description.text:
UPDATE 04/28/2017

  • I've added a short installation guide at the end of this page (Post-Printing section). Note that this is just a reference as I can't take pictures of the process to make a proper guide anymore (my printer has been thoroughly modded and it can't be called "stock" anymore to serve as a reference).

UPDATE 01/25/2017

  • For the people who has upgraded from the stock cooling solution (using DiiiCooler, Cobra, Thorped, etc) you can try printing without supports at all for the B versions of the files. You can certainly bridge the IEC connector hole without any problem if your printer is properly calibrated and the part is well cooled. Give it a try if you want to save some material.
    For the A versions, I would flip the model so it touches the build plate with the tabs where the fan mounts on. Again, know your machine and its capabilities before any attempt.

UPDATE 06/02/2016

  • Added a new full set of covers with the offset only on the top. These will be useful for those who don't want to use rubber feet under the PSU or just want to have the inclined plane on top (for any reason). They're based on v6, so they have all the previous corrections included. These are final versions too.

UPDATE 05/31/16

  • Added new covers with power plug socket on the top.

UPDATE 05/29/16 FINAL VERSION:

  • Added v5
    Corrected fan mounts so M4 screw threads catch the plastic deeper.

UPDATE 05/28/16:

  • Added v4
    People having trouble with supports falling off for the tabs on the inner corners can use this new version. It should use support only for the power connector socket and wiring loom hole. It uses more material but also reinforces corners a lot. Choose infill percentage wisely.

UPDATE 05/27/16:

  • Fixed power connector mounting holes (they're smaller now, M3x8mm screws or longer should work).
  • Reinforced fan mounting corners and psu mounting tabs.
  • Bigger fan mounting holes (should still be threaded when inserting fan screws).
  • Print orientation: place the psu mounting tabs on the bed.

UPDATE 05/26/16: Added chamfers to tabs for additional strength.

This is an extended back cover for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 PSU (also rebranded as Monoprice Maker Select, Balco 3D Printer, Cocoon Create). This model allows you to use a 120mm fan instead of the noisy tiny internal one. The new fan will be mounted outside of the power supply, but it will be much more silent.

As this part extends up and down to accomodate the bigger sized fan, you will need to put some adhesive rubber feet under the PSU to lift it up a bit. It is about 5mm of extra length in those directions.
UPDATE: By popular request, I uploaded new "Offset" versions that have the inclined plane only on the top of the cover. These ones won't need rubber feet installed under the PSU.

I don't know if other versions of the printer have a different arrangement for the screw holes. This was designed for a v2.1 (v2 should be the same). Check compatibility for v1 and rebranded versions before printing.

I used for reference the models by jamesarm97 and shaiss.

There are 2 versions of these files.

  • A models
    Needs supports for the inner corner tabs where the fan mounts on. Uses less material.

  • B models
    Doesn't need supports for the inner tabs where the fan mounts on. Uses more material. Recommended if you have problems with the supports falling off or unsticking from the build plate.

The stock screws won't work for this part. Use M3x8mm or longer to attach the cover to your PSU case. Screw holes aren't countersunk (just counterbored), so choose screws with a flat top.
Fan holes are 15mm deep in model B. Use self-tapping screws to mount the fan from the outside. M4x40mm screws (if using a 25mm deep fan) work also.

If using model A, you can also thread the screws from the inside and secure the fan with a washer and a nut on the outside. Make sure you don't use model B if you're going that route.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 v2.1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Place the model with the PSU mounting tabs facing the build plate. Enable supports for the IEC connector/power switch plate, wiring loom slot, and for the 4 inner corners where the fan mounts on (if you print model A).

It's not a must, but I recommend using 3 shells/solid perimeters for the holes where the fan mounts on, so when threading the screws the plastic doesn't break.

Extras

I recommend the addition of a fan grill to protect your fingers from the spinning blades. It is one of the drawbacks of having the fan exposed instead of inside the case. Be careful!

Installation guide

  1. Unplug the power cord from the wall socket and from the printer. Safety first!

  2. Unscrew the 4 black Philips screws that hold the sheet metal back cover in place. Save them if you plan to reinstall the stock cover in the future (they are too short to work with this mod).

  3. The cable loom going from the control box to the printer goes through a cut in the back plate and is held by a zip tie. Cut that zip tie to free the loom from the plate.

  4. Disconnect the spade connectors going to the IEC power socket + switch combo. Notice the wire colors and location to reinstall them later in the correct position. Take a picture if necessary.

  5. Disconnect the small fan from the power supply.

  6. Unscrew the fasteners holding the socket/switch in place. You should be able to lift it off the plate (use a flat screwdriver as leverage if you need so to get it out).

  7. Position the back cover and align it with the screw holes tapped in the case of the control box. Make sure the wire loom goes through the U-shaped cut-out provided.
    Use M3x8mm or longer to attach the plate to the metal case.

  8. Take the wires that were attached to the IEC connector/switch and guide them through the rectangular cutout provided (located on the top or sides, depending on the model you have printed). Re-attach the wires to the switch and screw it in back. You can reuse the stock screws that came with it (be gentle when doing this, you're threading into plastic).

  9. Take your 120mm fan and use the +12v and GND wires to connect it to the psu. If your fan has a molex connector (3 or 4 pin) you should be able to just plug the cable in to the existing connector you left coming from the power supply.
    You may want to use some electrical tape or a drop of hot glue to secure the connection.

  10. Align the fan with the mounting holes of the printed cover. Use M4x40mm screws or self-tappers of similar length to secure the fan to the cover. Make sure to tidy all the cables up inside so they don't catch on the fan blades.

  11. Enjoy your silent printer!

(OPTIONAL STEPS)

For better cooling and further noise reduction, you can remove the 60mm fan and metal cover for the power supply unit.

PLEASE note that you should know what you're doing and, at least, leave the printer unplugged for 24 hours before doing anything so the capacitors inside can release their charge and not shock you.

To do this you have to completely disassemble the control box. Take off the screws holding the top of the control box in place (they're on the botton, several tiny black Philips screws). Once loose, slide the top of the control box forward. You will have the top and bottom part separated now.

In case you go ahead, the metal case is held in place by a couple of Philips screws. Undoing them should release the case and give you access to the insides of the power supply. Unplug the fan connector, make sure there are no cables in the way that impide airflow and you're done.

I'm not responsible if you get hurt doing this step. Use some common sense!

title: LM8UU Bearing Holders For Orca 0.3 Y Axis

description.text:
Unless you want the Greg's Style holders please go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19950
everything has been updated and is working. I have deleted all the STL' s from this thing except for the Greg's style holders.
 Yet another LM8UU Linear Bearing Holder, this time for the Orca 0.3 Y, and Z Axis. It should work on the X axis as well but I have not included a belt clamp. There already seems to be some good x axis carriages out there. This is quite a comprehensive set of parts Y axis Greg's type to hold one or two lm8uu's if you like this kind of snap in bearing holder Y axis slot in lm8uu holders that capture the bearing against the aluminium plate of the squashed frog, this hopefully means that there should be no extra tolerances introduced due to the plastic parts. Both types are available with a single or double set of holders so you can use three lm8uu in total. v1 is a simple square type
v2 is a little more optimised and should use less plastic, but will either require to be printed with an over hang (this should work) or support material. The Z axis bearing holder is follows the same logic of trapping the bearing against the aluminium side frame. There are 3 versions, version 1 can also be used on the Y axis if you want to use a screw either side of the bearing instead of 2 to the side. You could use 2 v1 or v2 on the z axis, v3 allows you to use a single linear bearing or bush captured by both sets of mounting holes. The Z axis holder will through the spacing of the captive nut out so I have included a new back portion of the holder that should take up the the extra distance You may override the lm8uu dimensions in the SCAD file to use the bushings or linear bearings of your choice. The SCAD file is pretty parametric but I have no tested it with many configurations. For my set up I will use 1 x y_axis_v1 and 1 x z_axis_v1 for the Y frog and 2 x z_axis_v3 (modified for a 14mm x 37mm sintered bush)

To compile the SCAD file you will need a Prusa configuration.scad and the lm8uu Y axis holder file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9871. Print bearing holders of your choice, or edit the SCAD file to suit your machine Gregs Type:
Attach to the Y carriage using M4 x 20 cap screws the heads are blind so the holders should be attached before the bearings are inserted. Use M4 nylock nuts to secure. If using the Greg's type warm the holders with a hot air gun before inserting the bearings if you printed them from PLA, ABS might be OK without heating (I only print in PLA so I dont know for sure). Lock the bearing in place with a zip tie. Simple Type: Attach to the Y carriage using M4 x 30 cap screws. Use M4 nylock nuts to secure. (I am not sure if this will change the spacing of the Y rods on an existing machine slightly) Untested at the moment - I am still building my machine.

comments.text: I like it!  I printed mine in ABS, but I think the walls need to be thicker on the double-bearing holder for ABS.  There's too much flexion in the ABS.  But maybe I just need to tune my settings more.

comments.text: Ciao, ti volevo chiedere se potevi inserire i prezzi dei vari componenti che bisogna acquistare, così per farsi una idea della psesa che si va ad affrontare e se era possibile creare una guida per l'assemblaggio.
comments.author: pantera71

comments.text:
Ciao, la spesa maggiore da affrontare è sicuramente quella motori, su ebay li trovi per circa 65€ http://www.ebay.it/itm/N-5-Nema-17-stepper-motor-Wantai-42BYGHW609-/201222598467?hash=item2ed9cd2f43:g:f5wAAOSwnDxUm9NR hanno una coppia di 4Kg.cm invece di 4.8Kg.cm ma vanno bene lo stesso. Poi c'è l'elettronica con alimentatore da 12V 20A e dovresti spendere circa 40-50€. Per elettronica intendo ramps 1.4 assemblata con il clone di arduino mega senza display. Poi ci sono 3 barre lisce in acciaio non rettificate al prezzo di 15 € più s.s. e 2 pulegge gt2 con 2 mt di cinghia a circa 7€ http://www.ebay.it/itm/RepRap-2x-GT2-20T-5mm-Bore-Puleggia-2M-Timing-Belt-Set-Per-3D-printer-Prusa-HG-/282029306564?hash=item41aa41b2c4:g:x2kAAOSwQNRXLHrx Il piano di stampa riscaldato se lo vuoi mettere costa circa 25€ con il vetro in borosilicato. Il carrello dell'asse y in plexiglass tagliato al laser l'ho pagato 10€ in un negozio che si occupa di insegne al neon. Per tutti i cuscinetti la spesa dovrebbe essere di circa 30-40€. Le altre cose come barre filettate, dad,i bulloni, rondelle e viti si trovano nelle comuni ferramenta, mentre gli interruttori di finecorsa nei negozi di ricambi per elettrodomestici. Infine le parti stampate se hai un'amico che possiede una stampante 3d puoi comprare il filamento (ABS 1Kg circa 23 €) e te li fai stampare da lui. Le istruzioni di questa stampante non le ho fatte ma ci sono di quella più piccola che si chiama OpenRap mini, ma non ha le barre inclinate avanti e dietro e sono su www.openrap.cc
Stavo per dimenticare la cosa più importante, l'hotend. Sempre su ebay il clone e3d v6 lo puoi trovare per 25€ oppure il e3d lite6 originale 40€.

description.text:
This Sword, Forged from a mix of Gundanium and Unobtainium, emits a beam of light, though a process of Hydrogigntion, which, in a nutshell, magnetizes Hydrogen atoms and ignites them. The Slicing power of the blade increases as the number of magnetized Hydrogen atoms increases, and the wielder has TWO (2) of them, which can combine to form a bigger dual blade.
While this is effective in a NUMBER of ways, this also runs the risk of causing the extinction of all life on whatever planet or galaxy this blade is in, KZG Gundam never uses it except as a last resort.
An ideal place to utilize this blade would be in space as the number of dead stars can supply more than enough Hydrogen to fuel the needs of this energy- (and possibly life) consuming beast of a sword.

Resolution:

As high as possible (for future Updates)

Infill:

100% for sturdiness

title: Extruder drive gear for Ultimaker 2+ extended

description.text: Out of the box our UM2+ extended was not printing properly. We determined that the drive gear on the extruder stepper motor had spun on the shaft and would only give us good prints at very low speed. This is a longer version.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

.1

100%

Notes:

PLA material, minimal clean-up

Run your printer with the settings that give you the best accuracy, usually slow.

Once printed it will be very tight to install. I used a heat gun to warm it up and expand the ID before installing. There is a small lead in on one end to help ease the installation. Press the gear flush with the end of the shaft to avoid interference with the extruder housing.
